title: Shape As Substance
description: Looking at Kumasi and cities on the Swahili coast as built environments, and what historians can learn from studying urbanism in this way.

sections.name: Shape as Substance? Materiality and Urban Africa
The value of using materiality to draw larger conclusions about the history of globalization.
The Colonial Gaze and the Built Environment: Seeing and Unseeing African Cities
Reckoning or Restating: The values and limitations of studying historical urban African architecture and materialism
Behind the Buildings: The Influence of the Built Environment on African City Scholarship
Power and Privilege Through Urbanity: How People in the Past Fall Through the Cracks
Studying the Swahili Coast and Kumasi as Built Environments
Coupling of the Built Environment with Individual Narratives
African Architecture: Revealing the Complexities of the Built Environment of African Cities
Colonial Architecture Shaping Post-Independence Sentiments in Africa
Reading Built Environments to See Urban African History
The Secrets of African Cities Revealed Through Architecture
